learning_outcomes.description: Construct logically correct and mathematically sound proofs.

Apply concepts of logic, set theory, relations, induction, principles of counting, probability, algebraic structures and elementary number theory to mathematical problems in more advanced mathematical courses and to problems encountered in other fields of study.
Demonstrate an understanding and well-founded knowledge of the mathematics presented in this course and thus be able to apply techniques from this course to solve both familiar and novel problems
Select and use the appropriate level, style and means of written communication, using the symbolic, graphical, and diagrammatic forms relevant to the context
Understand some applications of mathematics to relevant fields, such as computer programming and logic.

assessments.due_date:
2/03/2026 - 29/05/2026

Marks will be assigned during the two-hour applied class by the casual academics based on discussions with students as they work on the open-ended task material.
assessments.task_description: For each applied class (weeks 2-13), your casual academic(s) will allocate marks based on your engagement with the material, which will be open-ended and exploratory in nature. There is no requirement to solve all of the problems, only to engage in the exploratory nature of the tasks. Your final percentage for the applied practical component of the course will be a combination of the weekly marks for 8 of the 12 applied classes, using whichever 8 applied classes give you the highest overall percentage.
assessments.submission_guidelines: There is no need to submit written material.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description: Each assignment requires you to answer a set of questions and submit your written solutions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit this assessment item through the link in Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
In-semester Saturday

28/03/2026 - 2/05/2026

Date: You must hold all of the following three Saturdays free until the exam date is officially announced

  • Saturday 28 March 2026 (Week 5)
  • Saturday 18 April 2026 (Week 7)
  • Saturday 2 May 2026 (Week 9)
assessments.task_description:
Internally enrolled students

The in-semester exam will be an in-person, paper-based exam. Students will sit the exam at the St Lucia Campus.

Externally enrolled students

The in-semester exam will be an in-person, paper-based exam for students within a 200 km radius of the St Lucia Campus. Students will sit the exam at the St Lucia Campus.

If you reside outside of a 200 km radius of the St Lucia Campus then you will sit the examination via Zoom. 

Important note: End-of-Semester exam arrangements may differ from the in-semester exam arrangements. Please refer to the End-of-Semester examination section of this profile to ensure you are familiar with the arrangements.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The end-of-semester exam will be held during the UQ exam period; the schedule will be provided by UQ Examinations.

The End of Semester Examination will be an in-person, paper-based exam for all students.

Internally enrolled students

The final exam will be an in-person, paper-based exam. Students will sit the exam at the St Lucia Campus.

Externally enrolled students

The final exam will be an in-person, paper-based exam. UQ Examinations will contact students directly to confirm arrangements. You will either sit the exam at the St Lucia campus (if you live within 200km radius of the campus) or will be directed to nominate an exam centre by a certain date.

Please ensure you update your semester address in Si-net at the start of the semester.

One reminder will be sent and students who fail to nominate an exam centre and will be automatically assigned to the St Lucia campus. Late nominations will not be accepted.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Pre-class videos, readings, and quizzes

To prepare for each class, you will need to watch one or two short videos, read some pages of the textbook, and complete a short quiz.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Each week there will be three hours of lectures during which you will discuss important concepts, work through examples, and answer questions.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures Each week there will be three hours of lectures during which you will discuss important concepts, work through examples, and answer questions.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 13(02 Mar - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Applied Classes

Applied classes give students a chance to ask questions relating to material covered in lectures, and to engage further with the course material through guided exploration. Applied classes also give students the opportunity to discuss with their peers approaches to formulating and solving mathematical problems.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

Applied classes also give students the opportunity to discuss with their peers approaches to formulating and solving mathematical problems.
